Chryseobacterium ginsenosidimutans is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected from a ginseng field in South Korea. It is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and non-motile bacterium that belongs to the genus Chryseobacterium, which is a part of the phylum Bacteroidetes.

The cells of C. ginsenosidimutans are yellow-pigmented, short rods, and they can grow at temperatures ranging from 10°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 30°C. This species is capable of hydrolyzing various compounds, including starch, casein, and Tween 80, and it can utilize a variety of carbon sources for growth.

One of the unique characteristics of C. ginsenosidimutans is its ability to transform ginsenosides, which are the primary bioactive compounds found in ginseng plants. This bacterium can convert certain ginsenosides into other forms, potentially enhancing the medicinal properties of ginseng products. Due to this ability, C. ginsenosidimutans has potential applications in the production of value-added ginseng-based products.

Overall, Chryseobacterium ginsenosidimutans is a soil-dwelling bacterium with the remarkable ability to modulate the chemical composition of ginseng, making it an interesting subject for further research and potential biotechnological applications.
